intro: This page is a quick walk-through so you can ship accounts fast without touching the backend.
quickTips: When you create a fresh user, set the status to on hold so it only starts counting after the first connection.
Always leave a short note (monthly, test, VIP) so future-you remembers what this account is for.
If someone says the link is broken, copy the subscription URL or QR from the table to generate a clean link.
Before deleting an account, revoke the subscription so old links stop working.
Pro tip: the Users search box accepts subscription links, tokens, keys, UUIDs, and full config links.

sections.title: Search users by links or IDs
sections.description: You can paste almost anything from a user and find them instantly.
steps: Paste a subscription URL (token, key, or username/key) into the Users search box.
Paste a config link (vless/vmess/trojan/shadowsocks) to find the owner.
You can also search by UUID, credential key, or raw token.
hints: If a user cannot connect, paste their exact config link to locate the account quickly.
Search accepts both plain values and full URLs.

sections.title: Get a single config
sections.description: When you need a one-off config for a user, grab it from the Links tab.
steps: On the Users page, click the edit icon for the user.
Open the "Links" tab.
Use the QR or copy button to grab the single config.
hints: QR is fastest for sharing to phones; copy is best for messaging.
If the subscription link is broken, the single config works as a fallback.

sections.title: Create user
sections.description: Create a user fast and hand over the link—no backend work needed.
steps: On the Users page, click “Create user” to open the dialog.
Fill username, status (active or on hold), expiry date, and data cap.
Choose service and inbounds so the right link is generated.
Set IP limit and add a note if needed.
Enable Auto Renew if you want hands-off renewals.
Save and share the link or QR with the user.
hints: Use on hold to keep it ready without starting the clock until first connect.
Add a short note so you remember why this account exists.
IP limit 1–2 makes sharing much harder.

sections.title: Renew user
sections.description: You don’t need a brand new user to extend time or quota.
steps: In the table, click the username or edit icon to open the user drawer.
Pick a new expiry date or increase the data limit.
If the user was blocked, switch the status back to "active" (or "limited" if you want to cap them).
Save your changes. The existing links keep working.
hints: Turn on Auto Renew if you want the account to extend itself when it hits time or quota.
Reset usage is available in the same dialog if you want to start counting from zero.

sections.title: On-hold user
sections.description: Use this when you want to hand over the link now but let activation wait for first connect.
steps: Set the status to "on hold" in the create/edit form.
Fill the "on hold duration" with 2-5 days so it expires if they never connect.
For safety, set the IP limit to 1 or 2.
Share the subscription link; after the first connection it becomes active and starts counting.
hints: If the on-hold window ends and they still haven’t connected, put it back on hold or delete it.
Once it turns active, you can extend traffic or time from the same dialog.

sections.title: My account
sections.description: See your own usage, API keys, and password from one place.
steps: Open "My account" from the sidebar.
Top cards show your used/remaining/total data and user limits.
Use the Daily usage chart with a date filter to review per-day traffic.
If allowed, Per node usage shows consumption per node.
In API Keys, create a key with 1/3/6/12 months or forever lifetime; delete old keys when you rotate.
In Change password, enter current + new password or use the random generator button.
hints: API keys are shown only once—copy immediately.
Prefer short-lived keys; delete and recreate if you suspect sharing.
If you lack self_api_keys or self_change_password, those cards stay hidden.
Narrow the date range for charts if you want faster loading.

sections.title: Nodes
sections.description: Three parts: overview, how to create/configure, and copying the secret + connectivity.

modalExample.title: Node certificate created
modalExample.copyHint: Copy this certificate and place it on the node.

subsections.title: Overview
subsections.description: Shows node status, service/API ports, usage coefficient, and total traffic per node.

subsections.title: How to set up
steps: Click Add node and fill name, domain/IP, service port, API port, usage coefficient, and optional data cap.
Add per-node xray_config / sing_config / hysteria_config if you need overrides; leave empty to inherit global settings.
If you use Nobetci, turn it on and set the monitor port.
After saving, the modal shows the unique secret; copy or download it right away (each node has its own).
Example: teh1.example.com with service port 62050 and API 62051; put the generated secret on that server.
After saving, check Hosts/Integrations to confirm connectivity.
hints: The secret appears only after saving; you can view it again from the node page.
Keep service/API ports open and server time in sync (NTP).
Use the usage coefficient for manual load balance; e.g., 2 for a stronger node.
Do not reuse the same secret across nodes; generate one per node.
If offline, check firewall, DNS, and Hosts settings.

sections.title: Admins
sections.description: Three parts: admin overview, how to manage, and admin roles (each role its own box).

subsections.title: Overview
subsections.description: Table shows role, status, data/user caps, and quick stats; filter to find faster.

subsections.title: How to manage
steps: Click Add admin, set username/password, and pick a role (Full Access / Sudo / Reseller / Standard).
Set data_limit and users_limit so their scope is bounded.
Use enable/disable to pause or resume the admin and their users.
Delete is a soft delete for the admin and their users; use the shortcut to open create-admin quickly.
hints: After raising limits or resetting usage, re-enable if still paused.
Keep Full Access rare; prefer Sudo/Standard for support teams.

subsections.title: Full Access
subsections.description: Owner-level control over all sections and sensitive settings (Users, Admins, Services, Hosts, Nodes, Integrations, settings).
steps: Create/edit roles, services, nodes, and integrations without restriction.
Set limits and permissions for other admins and users.
Reserve for the primary owner; keep the count low.
hints: Review permissions before handing this role to someone else.
Use strong passwords and 2FA for this role.

subsections.title: Sudo
subsections.description: High operational access without full ownership; ideal for senior support/ops.
steps: Create/edit users, services, and nodes (except owner-only settings).
Can handle most daily operations but limited on ownership changes.
Keep the number small to reduce risk.
hints: If they don’t need to manage Full Access, Sudo is enough.
Review limits and logs regularly.

subsections.title: Reseller
subsections.description: Seller/agent with defined data/user caps; manages only their own users.
steps: Create/manage their own users within users_limit and data_limit.
No access to sensitive system sections beyond what selling requires.
Use for partners with scoped access.
hints: On-hold users do not count toward users_limit; active ones do.
Set caps to match the contract scope.

subsections.title: Standard
subsections.description: Most limited; sees/edits only the sections you enable.
steps: Good for trainees or constrained support.
Each section (Users, Admins, Services, ...) must be enabled explicitly.
Self permissions decide which My Account cards show.
hints: For view-only, enable can_view and leave can_edit off.
Add permissions gradually if you plan to upgrade them.

dialogSections.title: Basics & status
dialogSections.description: Top of the form: identity, status, time and quota.

fields.name: Username
fields.detail: 3–32 chars; keep it simple and readable.
tips: Use trial/guest suffix for tests so they stand out.

fields.name: Status
fields.detail: active for normal use, on hold to start after first connect, limited/expired/disabled to pause or cap access.
tips: On hold holds expiry and quota until the first successful connection.

fields.name: Expire
fields.detail: End date; leave empty for no expiry.
tips: Quick add buttons (+30 days, etc.) sit above the table.

fields.name: Data limit (GB)
fields.detail: Quota in GB; leave empty for unlimited.
tips: For trials, 10–50 GB is usually enough.

fields.name: IP limit
fields.detail: Simultaneous IPs allowed; set to 1–2 to reduce sharing.

dialogSections.title: Service & inbounds
dialogSections.description: Pick how links are generated and which inbound/protocol to use.

fields.name: Service
fields.detail: If you use predefined plans, select one so settings auto-fill.

fields.name: Inbounds / protocols
fields.detail: Choose an inbound per protocol (vless/vmess/trojan/ss) so the user link is built.
tips: If the list is empty, add an inbound first under Hosts/Nodes.

fields.name: Flow / TLS
fields.detail: Optional flow (e.g., xtls-rprx-vision) or custom credential; leave blank if unsure.

dialogSections.title: Access keys & links
dialogSections.description: Subscription link and optional manual credential key.

fields.name: Manual credential key
fields.detail: Tick Manual to paste a custom 32-char key.

fields.name: Subscription link / QR
fields.detail: After saving, copy a fresh link or QR from the users table.

dialogSections.title: Auto Renew
dialogSections.description: Keep accounts alive without manual edits.

fields.name: Data limit
fields.detail: Quota to apply when the cap is reached.
tips: Use add remaining to carry leftover traffic into the next cycle.

fields.name: Time limit (days)
fields.detail: Days to add to expiry; zero means no time cap.

fields.name: Fire on either
fields.detail: If enabled, renews when either time or quota hits first.

dialogSections.title: Notes & contact
dialogSections.description: Support details so you remember who’s who.

fields.name: Note
fields.detail: Short context about the user or deal; helps searching later.

statuses.title: On Hold (waiting for first connect)
statuses.description: Account exists but hasn’t connected yet. First successful connection flips it to active and starts timers.
actions: Use it for trials or brand new customers.
If the on-hold timer runs out, either extend the timer or clean it up.
Keep the IP limit low to avoid link sharing.

statuses.title: Active (in use)
statuses.description: Normal state. Usage, expiry, and logs are tracked.
actions: Add quota or extend expiry whenever needed, or reset usage to start fresh.
If you want to pause without deleting, switch to disabled.

statuses.title: Limited (quota reached)
statuses.description: Data cap is hit and the connection is restricted.
actions: Add more quota, reset usage, or flip back to active after you charge them.
Enable Auto Renew with "add remaining" if you don’t want leftover traffic to vanish.

statuses.title: Expired (date passed)
statuses.description: Expiry is in the past and the user can’t connect.
actions: Move the expiry forward or reset usage and reactivate.
If it’s been dormant for a while, revoke the subscription and send a fresh link.

faqs.question: When should I use on hold?
faqs.answer: Whenever you don’t want the account to start until the customer actually connects.
bullets: Trial accounts that might never connect.
Customers who need to pay first, then activate.
Cases where you want to send the link early but start counting later.

faqs.question: What’s the fastest way to renew?
faqs.answer: Open the user dialog, change the expiry or quota, and save.
bullets: Turn on Auto Renew in the same dialog for hands-off renewals.
Use reset usage if you want to zero out their counters.

faqs.question: What’s the difference between active, on hold, and disabled?
faqs.answer: Active = full access; on hold = waiting for the first connection; disabled = paused until you change it back.

faqs.question: User says they can’t connect—where do I start?
faqs.answer: Check three things: status is active, expiry/quota aren’t blocking, and the link is current.
bullets: Grab a fresh QR or subscription link from the table.
If status is limited or expired, extend it as needed.
Lower the IP limit and reset usage if you suspect sharing.

faqs.question: What is a subscription and where do I create it?
faqs.answer: A subscription is the user account + link. Go to the Users page and click Create user to make one.
bullets: Data limit = quota cap (GB).
Time limit = expiry date; access stops after it.
Service = prebuilt plan with inbound/quota/expiry defaults.

faqs.question: Common questions about subscription settings
bullets: Auto delete: remove the user after time/quota ends.
Auto renew: renews traffic/time automatically.
Add remaining: carry leftover traffic into the next cycle.
Revoke access: invalidate old links (revoke subscription).
Reset usage: zero out usage counters.
Enable/disable: temporarily allow or block access.
How does it connect? Via the subscription link/QR in your V2Ray/Reality/SS client.

samples.note: Trial account; link sent but not connected yet.
Main customer; monthly renewal with auto renew on.
Quota exceeded; add data or reset usage.

panelIntro.title: Panel overview
panelIntro.description: Rebecca panel to create, manage, and troubleshoot users, admins, and nodes. Main areas: Dashboard, Users, Admins, Services, Hosts, Nodes, Integrations, My Account.
bullets: Create/renew users, statuses (active/on hold/limited/expired), links/QR, Auto Renew.
Admins with roles and permissions, data limit and user limit.
Nodes with per-node secret; monitor connectivity via Hosts/Integrations.
My Account: API keys, password change, daily and per-node usage charts.
Open source—if it helps you, please star the GitHub repo.
